thread.title: High school football: Timpview turns back Corner Canyon, all but clinches Region 7 crown
thread.title_full: High school football: Timpview turns back Corner Canyon, all but clinches Region 7 crown | Deseret News

author: Randy Hollis
title: High school football: Timpview turns back Corner Canyon, all but clinches Region 7 crown
text:
Timpview built a 21-0 lead in the third quarter, then turned back Corner Canyon's late comeback bid to essentially wrap up the Region 7 title.
Scoreboard » Timpview Corner Canyon 28 20 See more stats » More Coverage High school football roundup for Friday, Oct. 9 Wasatch defense shines in win over Maple Mountain DRAPER — The Thunderbirds were soaring along like their Air Force namesakes.
Timpview High had steadily built a 21-0 lead midway through the third quarter and was seemingly well on its way to another easy victory Friday night.
Then Corner Canyon caught fire as the Chargers, ignited by sophomore quarterback Zach Wilson , pulled within a touchdown, 21-14, with 7 1/2 minutes remaining, and Timpview suddenly found itself in a ballgame.
But the T-Birds, displaying the late-game composure, savvy and grit that has earned them three straight 4A state championships, held on for a 28-20 victory that essentially wrapped up this year's Region 7 title.
"This win was important," said Timpview coach Cary Whittingham , whose team improved to 5-0 in Region 7 and 7-1 overall with its sixth-straight victory, with only winless Mountain View remaining on the T-Birds' league schedule. "It put us in first place regardless, and so that's what we were hoping for right there.
"I credit Corner Canyon. They've got some good kids and they kept coming after us and after us and after us, and they made it a tough game. They gave us all we could handle."
Slender senior wide receiver Samson Nacua , who broke free for a 66-yard touchdown reception in the first quarter, hauled in another TD toss from senior quarterback Kahi Neves , this one from 22 yards away with 1:44 to play, to give the T-Birds a 28-14 lead and pretty much put it just out of Corner Canyon's reach.
"The safeties dropped back and I was telling (Neves) right before the play, 'You've got to throw me the ball right here and I'll make a play out of it. We've got to get our momentum going, so just give me the ball,'" Nacua said of his first TD catch.
"Then I broke the first tackle and I was just running and I saw the safety come after me and I thought, 'Oh, dude, he's gonna catch me," and then I tried jumping up and he barely missed me and I just walked into the end zone."
Asten Aspinall scored Timpview's second touchdown, powering in from a yard out on the first play of the second quarter, to make it 14-0. Then midway through the third quarter, Neves found Fielding Wallace behind the Chargers' defense for a picture-perfect 58-yard touchdown pass and a 21-0 lead.
Nacua admitted the T-Birds let up a bit after building a 21-point lead.
"We got too comfortable and they started coming back, and we had to pick our momentum up," he said. "We can't let that happen.
"Our defense was doing really good. They held 'em really good; they blocked kicks and field goals, and they did really good."
Corner Canyon wouldn't quit, battling back when Jason Adams bounced around the left side on a 10-yard touchdown burst, followed by Wilson's 12-yard TD pass to Chase Meyer that made it 21-14 with 7:31 remaining to play.
But Nacua's second TD catch made it 28-14, and Wilson's 15-yard scoring strike to Braxton Coon could only pull the Chargers within 28-20 with 1:01 to go before Timpview got the ball back and ran out the clock.
"He had some very good moments there," Whittingham said of Nacua. "He's been that way for us all season, and we expect that out of him and we need that out of him.
"The defense hung in there ... we just didn't play real well and that was the big difference there. We've still got some things we need to take care of. There's some things, obviously, we still need to take care of. We've got to address some penalty issues, we've got to address some coverage issues, technique for that coverage, and we've got to address some assignments as well.
"We've got a short week and we've got to get ready for Mountain View and move on from there," the Thunderbirds' coach said.
EMAIL: rhollis@desnews.com
